title: Spectrality of Moran-type measures with staggered contraction ratios

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Consider a Moran-type iterated function system (IFS) $\left\{\phi_{k, d}\right\}_{d \in D_{2 p_{k}}, k \geq 1}$, where each contraction map is defined as

$$
\phi_{k, d}(x)=(-1)^{d} b_{k}^{-1}(x+d)
$$

with integer sequences $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ and $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ satisfying $b_{k} \geq 2 p_{k} \geq 2$, and digit sets $D_{2 p_{k}}=\left\{0,1, \ldots, 2 p_{k}-1\right\}$ for all $k \geq 1$. We first prove that this IFS uniquely generates a Borel probability measure $\mu$. Furthermore, under the divisibility constraints

$$
p_{2} \mid b_{2}, \quad 2 \mid b_{2}, \quad \text { and } \quad 2 p_{k} \mid b_{k} \text { for } k \geq 3
$$

with $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ bounded, we prove that $\mu$ is a spectral measure, that is, $L^{2}(\mu)$ admits an orthogonal basis of exponentials. To fully characterize the spectral properties, we introduce a multi-stage decomposition strategy for spectrums. By imposing the additional hypothesis that all parameters $p_{k}$ are even, we establish a complete characterization of $\mu$ 's spectrality. This result unifies and extends the frameworks proposed in $[2,9,32]$, providing a generalized criterion for such measures.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

A Borel set $\Omega \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with positive, finite Lebesgue measure is termed a spectral set if the space $L^{2}(\Omega)$ admits an orthogonal basis of exponential functions. This concept, central to functional analysis, gained prominence with Fuglede's 1974 conjecture [12], which posited that $\Omega$ is a spectral set if and only if it tiles $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ translationally, i.e., there exists $\mathcal{J} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that $\{\Omega+t: t \in \mathcal{J}\}$ partitions $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. While disproven in dimensions $n \geq 3$ by Tao, Kolountzakis and Matolcsi [31, 27, 17, 18], the conjecture remains unresolved for $n=1,2$. Recent breakthroughs by Lev and Matolcsi [20] established its validity under convexity constraints across all dimensions, revitalizing interest in restricted cases.

The development of harmonic analysis and fractal geometry has propelled spectral measures, generalizations of spectral sets, to the forefront of mathematical inquiry. Formally, a compactly supported Borel probability measure $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ is called a

Identifying such measures, particularly among singular fractal measures, constitutes a pivotal challenge in modern analysis. Seminal work by Jorgensen and Pedersen [16] revealed that the $\frac{1}{n}$-Cantor measure $\mu_{1 / n}$ is spectral if and only if $n$ is even. Subsequent advancements extended this to self-similar measures [19], where Dai, He, and Lau [8] characterized that a self-similar measure $\mu_{\rho}$ with a consecutive digit set $D_{N}=\{0,1, \ldots, N-1\}$ is a spectral measure if and only if the reciprocal of its contraction ratio $p=\rho^{-1}$ is an integer and $N \mid p$. Parallel developments resolved long-standing questions on Bernoulli convolutions [14, 7], while self-affine measures and infinite convolutions were systematized through Hadamard triples $[3,11,21,22,23]$.

Moran-type measures, as natural extensions of self-similar and self-affine measures, exhibit intricate infinite product structures. Strichartz [29] pioneered their spectral analysis in 2000. Later, An and He [2] concerned the Moran-type measure $\mu_{\left\{b_{k}\right\},\left\{D_{p_{k}}\right\}}$ generated by a sequence of integers $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ with $b_{k} \geq 2$ and a sequence of consecutive digit sets $\left\{D_{p_{k}}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ with $p_{k} \geq 2$ by proving sufficiency of divisibility conditions $\left(p_{k} \mid b_{k}\right)$ for spectrality. Recent work by An, Li and Zhang [5] and Deng and Li [9] established necessity, culminating in a complete characterization. Current research explores generalized Moran-type measures under varied constraints $[1,4,10,13,24,25,26,28,30,33]$, demonstrating their rich spectral properties.

Notably, all preceding achievements on spectrality of fractal measures fundamentally rely on the uniformity of linear components in their defining contraction maps. A paradigm shift emerged through Wu's recent work [32], which constructed the first self-similar spectral measure $\mu_{ \pm \rho}$ with staggered contraction ratios $\pm \rho$ and consecutive digit set $D_{2 N}$. The study established a sharp characterization: $\mu_{ \pm \rho}$ is spectral if and only if the reciprocal of contraction parameter $p=\rho^{-1}$ is an integer and satisfies $2 N \mid p$.

Building on this conceptual breakthrough, we systematically investigate the spectrality of a novel class of Moran-type measures on $\mathbb{R}$ featuring hierarchically staggered contraction ratios. Our approach diverges from classical methodologies. We first rigorously establish the existence and uniqueness of Moran-type measures through Moran-type iterated function systems, then study their spectral properties by revealing intrinsic arithmetic constraints in non-uniform scaling systems.

Definition 1.1. Let $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty},\left\{n_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be two sequences of integer numbers with all $b_{k} \geq n_{k} \geq 2$ and let $\Phi_{k}=\left\{\phi_{k, i}\right\}_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1}$ be a family of contracting similitudes on $\mathbb{R}$ for each $k \geq 1$, where

$$
\phi_{k, i}(x)=(-1)^{i} b_{k}^{-1}(x+i), \quad \begin{aligned}
& x \in \mathbb{R} \quad\left(i=0,1, \ldots, n_{k}-1\right) \\
& 2
\end{aligned}
$$

We call the sequence $\left\{\Phi_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ a Moran-type iterated function system (IFS) with staggered contraction ratios.

Theorem 1.2. Let $\left\{\Phi_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be the Moran-type IFS as in Definition 1.1, then the following two statements hold:
(i) There exists a unique sequence of nonempty compact sets $\left\{E_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ in $\mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
E_{k}=\Phi_{k}\left(E_{k+1}\right):=\bigcup_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \phi_{k, i}\left(E_{k+1}\right), \quad k \geq 1
$$

and

$$
\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty}\left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)-\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}\left(a_{l+1}\right)\right|=0
$$

uniformly for all sequences $\left\{j_{l}: 0 \leq j_{l} \leq n_{l}-1\right\}_{l=k}^{\infty}$ and any $a_{l+1} \in E_{l+1}$.
(ii) There exists a unique sequence of probability measures $\left\{\mu_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ satisfying

$$
\mu_{k}=\frac{1}{n_{k}} \mu_{k+1} \circ \Phi_{k}^{-1}:=\sum_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \frac{1}{n_{k}} \mu_{k+1} \circ \phi_{k, i}^{-1}, \quad k \geq 1
$$

where each $\mu_{k}$ is supported on $E_{k}$.
The first measure $\mu:=\mu_{1}$ is called a Moran-type measure with staggered contraction ratios, which will be our research object throughout the paper. The supporting set $E_{1}$ is usually called a Moran-type set. The geometric fashion and Hausdorff dimension of Moran-type sets were investigated in detail by Hua et al. [15].

Theorem 1.3. Let $\left\{\Phi_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be the Moran-type IFS as in Definition 1.1 with assumption that the sequence $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is bounded and $2 \mid n_{k}$ for all $k \geq 1$. Let $\mu:=\mu_{1}$ be as in (1.4). Then $\mu$ is a spectral measure if $2\left|b_{2}, n_{2}\right| 2 b_{2}$ and $n_{k} \mid b_{k}$ for $k \geq 3$.

The necessity of this condition generally fails to hold, as demonstrated by the counterexample in Theorem 4.3 (Section 4). However, under the additional hypothesis that 4 divides all $n_{k}$, we give a complete characterization of the spectrality of $\mu$ in the next theorem. This result unifies and extends the frameworks proposed in $[2,9,32]$, providing a generalized criterion for such measures.

Theorem 1.4. Let $\left\{\Phi_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be the Moran-type IFS as in Definition 1.1 with assumption that the sequence $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is bounded and $4 \mid n_{k}$ for all $k \geq 1$. Let $\mu:=\mu_{1}$ be as in (1.4). Then $\mu$ is a spectral measure if and only if $n_{2} \mid 2 b_{2}$ and $n_{k} \mid b_{k}$ for $k \geq 3$.

The primary challenges in establishing these theorems stem from two fundamental considerations. First, unlike classical self-similar measures, the Moran-type measure $\mu$ lacks a convolutional structure, which precludes direct analysis via the framework of infinite convolution measures. Notably, by leveraging the iterative relation (1.4),

we demonstrate that its spectrality can be equivalently characterized through an infinite convolution (Proposition 4.2). Second, in addressing the necessity condition of Theorem 1.4, we introduce a multi-stage decomposition strategy for spectrums (Remark 5.2). This approach enables the extraction of hierarchical constraints by recursively partitioning the spectrum of the spectral measure.

A natural extension lies in investigating the spectral consistency across the sequence of measures $\left\{\mu_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$. For some typical Moran-type measures, Liu et al. [25] recently showed that spectrality of $\mu_{1}$ propagates inductively to all $\mu_{k}(k \geq 1)$. Nevertheless, the general case remains an open question, as the interplay between scaling parameters and spectral inheritance mechanisms resists straightforward generalization.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 synthesizes foundational results, including the Fourier transform of measures and some criteria for identifying spectral measures. Section 3 establishes Theorem 1.2, while Sections 4 and 5 develop the proofs of Theorems 1.3 and 1.4, respectively.

# 2. Preliminaries 

Let $\mu$ be a Borel probability measure on $\mathbb{R}$, the Fourier transform of $\mu$ is defined by

$$
\widehat{\mu}(t)=\int e^{2 \pi i t x} d \mu(x), t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

We denote by $\mathcal{Z}(\widehat{\mu}):=\{t \in \mathbb{R}: \widehat{\mu}(t)=0\}$ the zero set of $\widehat{\mu}$. Let $\Lambda \subset \mathbb{R}$ be a countable set, then the set $E(\Lambda)=\left\{e^{2 \pi i \lambda x}: \lambda \in \Lambda\right\}$ is an orthogonal set of $L^{2}(\mu)$ if and only if

$$
(\Lambda-\Lambda) \backslash\{0\} \subset \mathcal{Z}(\widehat{\mu})
$$

If this is the case, then $\Lambda$ is called a bi-zero set of $\mu$. Moreover, if $\Lambda$ is a bi-zero set of $\mu$ but $\Lambda \cup\{\alpha\}$ is not a bi-zero set for any $\alpha \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \Lambda$, then we call $\Lambda$ a maximal bi-zero set of $\mu$. The following is a basic criterion for determining $\Lambda$ to be a bi-zero set or spectrum of $\mu$.

Theorem 2.1 ([16]). Let $\Lambda$ be a countable subset of $\mathbb{R}$ and

$$
Q_{\Lambda, \mu}(t):=\sum_{\lambda \in \Lambda}|\widehat{\mu}(t+\lambda)|^{2}, \quad t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

Then
(i) $\Lambda$ is a bi-zero set of $\mu$ if and only if $Q_{\Lambda, \mu}(t) \leq 1$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$;
(ii) $\Lambda$ is a spectrum of $\mu$ if and only if $Q_{\Lambda, \mu}(t)=1$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$.

Lemma 2.2 ([8]). Let $\mu=\nu * \omega$ be a convolution of two measures, and let $\Lambda$ be a bi-zero set of $\nu$. Then $\Lambda$ is also a bi-zero set of $\mu$, but it can not be a spectrum of $\mu$ when $\omega$ is not a Dirac measure.

Lemma 2.3. For any $c \in \mathbb{R} \backslash\{0\}$, the measure $\mu$ is a spectral measure if and only if $\mu^{\prime}:=\mu(c \cdot)$ is a spectral measure.

Proof. If $\mu$ is a spectral measure with a spectrum $\Lambda$, for any $t \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{c \Lambda, \mu^{\prime}}(t) & =\sum_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\left|\widehat{\mu^{\prime}}(t+c \lambda)\right|^{2} \\
& =\sum_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\left|\int e^{2 \pi i(t+c \lambda) x} d \mu(c x)\right|^{2} \\
& =\sum_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\left|\int e^{2 \pi i\left(\frac{t}{c}+\lambda\right) y} d \mu(y)\right|^{2} \\
& =\sum_{\lambda \in \Lambda}\left|\widehat{\mu}\left(\frac{t}{c}+\lambda\right)\right|^{2} \equiv 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $\mu^{\prime}$ is also a spectral measure. Likewise for the other hand.
For any $n \in \mathbb{Z} \backslash\{0\}$, we let $v_{2}(n)$ be the greatest integer $k \geq 0$ such that $2^{k}$ divides $n$ in $\mathbb{Z}$, that is, $2^{-k} n \in 2 \mathbb{Z}+1$ and let $v_{2}(0)=\infty$. For any rational number $\frac{m}{n} \in \mathbb{Q}$ with $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$ where $n \neq 0$, we define

$$
v_{2}\left(\frac{m}{n}\right)=v_{2}(m)-v_{2}(n)
$$

Recently, Deng and Li [10] gave a necessary and sufficient condition for the spectrality of the Moran-type Bernoulli covolution of the form

$$
\mu=\delta_{b_{1}^{-1}\left\{0, d_{1}\right\}} * \delta_{\left(b_{1} b_{2}\right)^{-1}\left\{0, d_{2}\right\}} * \cdots * \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k}\right)^{-1}\left\{0, d_{k}\right\}} * \cdots
$$

where $b_{k}, d_{k}$ are integers.
Theorem 2.4 ([10]). For the above $\mu$ with $\left|b_{k}\right|>\left|d_{k}\right|$ for all $k \geq 2$. Assume futher that the sequence $\left\{\left|d_{k}\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is bounded. Then $\mu$ is a spectral measure if and only if $s_{i} \neq s_{j}$ for all $j>i \geq 1$, where

$$
s_{k}=v_{2}\left(\frac{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{k}}{2 d_{k}}\right), \quad k=1,2, \ldots
$$

Definition 2.5. Let $R$ be an integer satisfying $|R|>1$, and $B, L \subset \mathbb{Z}$ be finite integer sets with the same cardinality $\# B=\# L \geq 2$. If the matrix

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{\# B}}\left(e^{-2 \pi i R^{-1} b \ell}\right)_{b \in B, \ell \in L}
$$

is unitary, we call $(R, B, L)$ a Hadamard triple in $\mathbb{R}$.
The Hadamard triple is an important tool in studying the spectrality of measures as it is closely related to the spectrum of a discrete measure. Let $A$ be a finite subset

of $\mathbb{R}$, we define a discrete measure on $A$ by

$$
\delta_{A}=\frac{1}{\# A} \sum_{a \in A} \delta_{a}
$$

where $\delta_{a}$ is the Dirac measure at $a$. Moreover, we also define the mask polynomial of the set $A$ by

$$
m_{A}(x)=\frac{1}{\# A} \sum_{a \in A} e^{2 \pi i a x}, x \in \mathbb{R}
$$

The mask polynomial is obviously equal to the Fourier transform of the discrete measure $\delta_{A}$. Trivially, $(R, B, L)$ is a Hadamard triple if and only if $L$ is a spectrum of the measure $\delta_{R^{-1} B}[11]$.

Lemma 2.6 ([22]). If $\left\{\left(N_{j}, B_{j}, L_{j}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{n}$ are finitely many Hadamard triples in $\mathbb{R}$, let

$$
N=N_{1} N_{2} \cdots N_{n}, \quad B=\left(N_{2} \cdots N_{n}\right) B_{1}+\cdots+N_{n} B_{n-1}+B_{n}
$$

and

$$
L=L_{1}+N_{1} L_{2}+\cdots+\left(N_{1} N_{2} \cdots N_{n-1}\right) L_{n}
$$

then $(N, B, L)$ is a Hadamard triple.
Let $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be a sequence of Hadamard triples in $\mathbb{R}$, the infinite convolution generated by the Hadamard triples is defined by

$$
\mu=\delta_{N_{1}^{-1} B_{1}} * \cdots * \delta_{\left(N_{1} \cdots N_{k}\right)^{-1} B_{k}} * \cdots
$$

which is usually represented as a convolution of two measures

$$
\mu=\mu_{k} * \mu_{>k}
$$

where

$$
\mu_{k}=\delta_{N_{1}^{-1} B_{1}} * \cdots * \delta_{\left(N_{1} \cdots N_{k}\right)^{-1} B_{k}}
$$

and

$$
\mu_{>k}=\delta_{\left(N_{1} \cdots N_{k+1}\right)^{-1} B_{k+1}} * \delta_{\left(N_{1} \cdots N_{k+1} N_{k+2}\right)^{-1} B_{k+2}} * \cdots
$$

Under the assumption that $B_{k} \subset\left\{0,1, \ldots, N_{k}-1\right\}$ for all $k \geq 1$, An et al. [1] found a sufficient condition for spectrality of the infinite convolution $\mu$.

Lemma 2.7 ([1]). Suppose that $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is a sequence of Hadamard triples with $B_{k} \subset\left\{0,1, \ldots, N_{k}-1\right\}$ for all $k \geq 1$. Suppose that

$$
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \# B_{k}<\infty
$$

Then the infinite convolution $\mu$ as in (2.1) is a spectral measure and it always admits a spectrum in $\mathbb{Z}$.

The integral periodic zero set of a Borel probability measure $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}$ is defined to be the set

$$
Z(\mu)=\{\xi \in \mathbb{R}: \widehat{\mu}(\xi+k)=0 \text { for all } k \in \mathbb{Z}\}
$$

Let $\mathcal{P}(E)$ be the set of all Borel probability measures on $E \subset \mathbb{R}$. A family of measures $\Psi \subset \mathcal{P}(E)$ is called an admissible family if $Z(\mu)=\emptyset$ for every $\mu \in \operatorname{cl}(\Psi)$, the closure of $\Psi$ with respect to the weak topology on $\mathcal{P}(E)$. We say that $\Psi$ is tight if for each $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a compact subset $K \subset \mathbb{R}$ such that $\inf _{\mu \in \Psi} \mu(K)>1-\varepsilon$.

Lemma 2.8 ([1]). Let $\mu \in \mathcal{P}([0,1])$. Then $Z(\mu) \neq \emptyset$ if and only if $\mu=\frac{1}{2}\left(\delta_{0}+\delta_{1}\right)$.
Let $\mu=\mu_{k} * \mu_{>k}$ be as in (2.1). We define

$$
\omega_{>k}(\cdot)=\mu_{>k}\left(\frac{\cdot}{N_{1} \cdots N_{k}}\right)
$$

That is,

$$
\omega_{>k}=\delta_{N_{k+1}^{-1} B_{k+1}} * \delta_{\left(N_{k+1} N_{k+2}\right)^{-1} B_{k+2}} * \cdots
$$

Theorem 2.9 ([22]). Let $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be a sequence of Hadamard triples in $\mathbb{R}$, suppose that infinite convolution measure $\mu$ defined by (2.1) exists. If there exists a subsequence $\left\{\omega_{>n_{j}}\right\}$ which is tight and addmissible, then $\mu$ is a spectral measure with a spectrum in $\mathbb{Z}$.

Theorem 2.10 ([23]). Let $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be a sequence of Hadamard triples in $\mathbb{R}$, suppose that infinite convolution measure $\mu$ defined by (2.1) exists. If there exists a subsequence $\left\{\omega_{>n_{j}}\right\}$ which converges weakly to $\omega$, and $Z(\omega)=\emptyset$, then $\mu$ is a spectral measure with a spectrum in $\mathbb{Z}$.

If the sequence of Hadamard triples $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ only has a finite number of different elements, then the following consequences are clear.

Lemma 2.11 ([22]). Let $\left\{\left(N_{j}, B_{j}, L_{j}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{m}$ be finitely many Hadamard triples, and let $\Sigma=\{1,2, \ldots, m\}^{\mathbb{N}}$. For $\sigma=\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2} \cdots \in \Sigma$, define

$$
\mu_{\sigma}=\delta_{N_{\sigma_{1}}^{-1} B_{\sigma_{1}}} * \cdots * \delta_{\left(N_{\sigma_{1}} \cdots N_{\sigma_{k}}\right)^{-1} B_{\sigma_{k}}} * \cdots
$$

Let $\Psi=\left\{\mu_{\sigma}: \sigma \in \Sigma\right\}$. Then we have $c l(\Psi)=\Psi$.
Lemma 2.12 ([23]). Suppose that $\left\{\left(N_{k}, B_{k}, L_{k}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is chosen from a finite set of Hadamard triples. If for each $k \geq 1$,

$$
\operatorname{gcd}\left(\bigcup_{j=k}^{\infty}\left(B_{j}-B_{j}\right)\right)=1
$$

then $Z(\mu)=\emptyset$, where $\mu$ is as in (2.1).
The final useful lemma is due to Deng and $\mathrm{Li}[9]$.

Lemma 2.13 ([9]). Let $p_{i, j}$ be positive numbers such that $\sum_{j=1}^{n} p_{i, j}=1(i=$ $1,2, \ldots, m)$ and $x_{i, j} \geq 0$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{m} \max _{1 \leq j \leq n}\left\{x_{i, j}\right\} \leq 1$. Then $\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{m} p_{i, j} x_{i, j}=$ 1 if and only if $\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i, 1}=1$ and $x_{i, 1}=x_{i, 2}=\cdots=x_{i, n}$ for $1 \leq i \leq m$.

# 3. Existence and uniqueness of Moran-type measures 

In this section, we establish the theory of Moran-type IFS and show the existence and uniqueness of the Moran-type measure by proving Theorem 1.2.

Proof of Theorem 1.2.
(i) Since $\Phi_{k}=\left\{\phi_{k, i}\right\}_{i=1}^{n_{k}}$ is a family of contracting similitudes on $\mathbb{R}$ and $b_{k} \geq n_{k} \geq$ $2(k \geq 1)$. For any $l \geq k, m \geq 1$ and for all sequences $\left\{j_{l}: 0 \leq j_{l} \leq n_{l}-1\right\}_{l=k}^{\infty}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)-\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l+m, j_{l+m}}(0)\right| \\
= & \left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}\left(0-\phi_{l+1, j_{l+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l+m, j_{l+m}}(0)\right)\right| \\
= & b_{k}^{-1} b_{k+1}^{-1} \cdots b_{l}^{-1} \cdot\left|\sum_{i=1}^{m}(-1)^{j_{l+1}+\cdots+j_{l+i}} b_{l+1}^{-1} \cdots b_{l+i}^{-1} \cdot j_{l+i}\right| \\
= & b_{k}^{-1} b_{k+1}^{-1} \cdots b_{l}^{-1} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{m} b_{l+1}^{-1} \cdots b_{l+i}^{-1} \cdot j_{l+i} \\
\leq & 2^{k-l+2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies

$$
\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\substack{0 \leq j_{l} \leq n_{l}-1 \\ k \leq i \leq l+m, m \geq 1}}\left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)-\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l+m, j_{l+m}}(0)\right|=0
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)\right| & \leq b_{k}^{-1} \cdot j_{k}+\cdots+b_{k}^{-1} \cdots b_{l}^{-1} \cdot j_{l} \\
& <1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2^{l-k}}<2
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the sequence $\left\{\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)\right\}_{l=k}^{\infty}$ is uniformly bounded in $[-2,2]$. Together with (3.1), we can get that the sequence $\left\{\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0)\right\}_{l=k}^{\infty}$ converges uniformly for all sequences $\left\{j_{l}: 0 \leq j_{l} \leq n_{l}-1\right\}_{l=k}^{\infty}$.

For each $k \geq 1$, define

$$
E_{k}=\left\{\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty} \phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{l}}(0): 0 \leq j_{i} \leq n_{i}-1, k \leq i \leq l\right\}
$$

Obviously, $\left\{E_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ satisfies (1.2). We just need to show the compactness of $E_{k}$.
From (3.2), it follows that $E_{k} \subset[-2,2]$ for each $k \geq 1$, hence $\left\{E_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is uniformly bounded. Let $\left\{x_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ be a Cauchy sequence of $E_{k}$, then for every $x_{n}$, there is a sequence $\left\{j_{n, i}\right\}_{i=k}^{\infty}$ such that

$$
x_{n}=\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty} \phi_{k, j_{n, k}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, j_{n, l}}(0)
$$

Since $0 \leq j_{n, k} \leq n_{k}-1$, there exists $\eta_{k}$ such that the index set $\left\{n: j_{n, k}=\eta_{k}\right\}$ is infinite. Repeating this process, there are $\eta_{k+1}, \eta_{k+2}, \ldots, \eta_{l}, \ldots$ such that the index set $\left\{n: j_{n, i}=\eta_{i}, i=k, \ldots, l\right\}$ is infinite for all $l \geq k$. Let

$$
x=\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty} \phi_{k, \eta_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, \eta_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{l, \eta_{l}}(0)
$$

By (3.1), for any $\varepsilon>0$, there is an integer $N>k$ such that for any $m, n \geq N$,

$$
\left|\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{m, j_{m}}(0)-\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{n, j_{n}}(0)\right|<\varepsilon
$$

That is, $E_{k}$ is contained in the $\varepsilon$-neighborhood of the set $\left\{\phi_{k, j_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, j_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ\right.$ $\left.\phi_{N, j_{N}}(0): 0 \leq j_{i} \leq n_{i}-1, i=k, \ldots, N\right\}$. $$
\begin{aligned}
\left|x-x_{l}\right| \leq & \left|x-x_{n}\right|+\left|x_{n}-x_{l}\right| \\
\leq & \left|x-x_{n}\right|+\varepsilon \\
\leq & \left|x-\phi_{k, \eta_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, \eta_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{N, \eta_{N}}(0)\right| \\
& +\left|\phi_{k, \eta_{k}} \circ \phi_{k+1, \eta_{k+1}} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{N, \eta_{N}}(0)-x_{n}\right|+\varepsilon \\
\leq & 3 \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

$$

uniformly for all sequences $\left\{j_{i}: 0 \leq j_{l} \leq n_{i}-1\right\}_{i=k}^{\infty}$. Thus (1.3) follows and the existence is proved.

Next we prove the uniqueness. Suppose $\left\{F_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ is another sequence of compact sets on $\mathbb{R}$ satisfying (1.2). Let $x \in F_{k}$. (1.2) shows that there exist $x_{i} \in F_{i}$ and $0 \leq j_{i} \leq n_{i}-1$ for $i=k+1, k+2, \ldots$ such that

(ii) For each $k \geq 1$, we denote by the symbolic space starting from the $k$-th level

and denote by the corresponding cylinder sets of $\Sigma_{k}$

\rho_{k}\left(j_{k} \cdots j_{i} \cdots, j_{k}^{\prime} \cdots j_{i}^{\prime} \cdots\right)=2^{-\min \left\{i: j_{i} \neq j_{i}^{\prime}\right\}}

then $\left(\Sigma_{k}, \rho_{k}\right)$ is a compact metric space, and the cylinder sets $\left[j_{k} \cdots j_{i}\right]$ are the open sets of the space. If we put a mass on every cylinder set of $\Sigma_{k}$ as follows:

$$
\omega_{k}\left(\left[j_{k} \cdots j_{i}\right]\right)=n_{k}^{-1} \cdots n_{i}^{-1}, \quad i \geq k

$$
L\left(\nu, \nu^{\prime}\right)=\sup _{\operatorname{Lip}(g) \leq 1}\left|\int g d \nu-\int g d \nu^{\prime}\right|
$$

where $\operatorname{Lip}(g)=\sup _{x \neq y} \frac{|g(x)-g(y)|}{|x-y|}$ is the Lipschitz constant of $g$. Then $(\mathcal{P}([-2,2]), L)$ is a compact metric space [6]. Let $g:[-2,2] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a function with $\operatorname{Lip}(g) \leq 1$, and let

$$
h=\sum_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \frac{1}{n_{k}} g \circ \phi_{k, i}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
|h(x)-h(y)| & =\sum_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \frac{1}{n_{k}}\left|g \circ \phi_{k, i}(x)-g \circ \phi_{k, i}(y)\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \frac{1}{n_{k}}\left|g \circ \phi_{k, i}(x)-g \circ \phi_{k, i}(y)\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{i=0}^{n_{k}-1} \frac{1}{n_{k}} \cdot b_{k}^{-1} \cdot|x-y| \\
& \leq b_{k}^{-1} \cdot|x-y|
\end{aligned}
$$

That is, $\operatorname{Lip}(h) \leq b_{k}^{-1}<1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\int g d \mu_{k}-\int g d \mu_{k}^{\prime}\right| & =\left|\int h d \mu_{k+1}-\int h d \mu_{k+1}^{\prime}\right| \\
& \leq \operatorname{Lip}(h) L\left(\mu_{k+1}, \mu_{k+1}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq b_{k}^{-1} L\left(\mu_{k+1}, \mu_{k+1}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $L\left(\mu_{k}, \mu_{k}^{\prime}\right) \leq b_{k}^{-1} L\left(\mu_{k+1}, \mu_{k+1}^{\prime}\right) \leq \cdots \leq b_{k}^{-n} L\left(\mu_{k+n}, \mu_{k+n}^{\prime}\right)$ for any $n \geq 1$. By letting $n \rightarrow \infty$, it concludes that $L\left(\mu_{k}, \mu_{k}^{\prime}\right)=0$. Therefore, $\mu_{k} \equiv \mu_{k}^{\prime}$, proving the uniqueness.

# 4. Proof of Theorem 1.3 

In this section, we study the spectrality of the Moran-type measure $\mu:=\mu_{1}$ defined in (1.4). Throughout the section, we assume that $n_{k}$ 's are all even numbers, i.e., $n_{k}=2 p_{k}$ where $p_{k} \in \mathbb{N}$ for $k \geq 1$. The sequence of measures $\left\{\mu_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ can be reformulated as

$$
\mu_{k}=\sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \mu_{k+1} \circ \phi_{k, j}^{-1}, \quad k \geq 1
$$

Lemma 4.1. Let $\mu:=\mu_{1}$ be the Moran-type measure defined by the above, then its Fourier transform is

$$
\widehat{\mu}(t)=e^{-b_{1}^{-1} \pi t i} \prod_{k=1}^{\infty} f_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right), \quad t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

where $f_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1} \cos \left(4 j+1-b_{k+1}^{-1}\right) \pi t$.
Proof. From (4.1), the Fourier transform of $\mu$ has the expression

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\mu}_{k}(t) & =\sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \widehat{\mu_{k+1} \circ \phi_{k, j}^{-1}}(t) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \int e^{2 \pi i t x} d \mu_{k+1} \circ \phi_{k, j}^{-1}(x) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \int e^{2 \pi i t(-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1}(x+j)} d \mu_{k+1}(x) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} e^{2 \pi i t(-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1} j} \int e^{2 \pi i t(-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1} x} d \mu_{k+1}(x) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} e^{2 \pi i t(-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1} j} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left((-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1} t\right), \quad t \in \mathbb{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

By considering the real and imaginary parts, denoted by ' $\mathrm{Re}^{\prime}$ and ' Im ', respectively, we have

$$
\widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left((-1)^{j} b_{k}^{-1} t\right)=\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(b_{k}^{-1} t\right)+i(-1)^{j} \operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(b_{k}^{-1} t\right)
$$

Hence

$$
\binom{\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{k}(t)}{\operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{k}(t)}=M_{k}\left(b_{k}^{-1} t\right)\binom{\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(b_{k}^{-1} t\right)}{\operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(b_{k}^{-1} t\right)}
$$

where the function matrix $M_{k}(t)=\left(\begin{array}{ll}a_{k, 1}(t) & a_{k, 2}(t) \\ a_{k, 3}(t) & a_{k, 4}(t)\end{array}\right)$ is given by

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
a_{k, 1}(t)=\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \cos 2 \pi t j, & a_{k, 2}(t)=-\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1} \sin 2 \pi t j \\
a_{k, 3}(t)=\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1}(-1)^{j} \sin 2 \pi t j, & a_{k, 4}(t)=\frac{1}{2 p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{2 p_{k}-1}(-1)^{j} \cos 2 \pi t j
\end{array}
$$

By iterating (4.2), one can get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \binom{\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{1}(t)}{\operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{1}(t)} \\
= & M_{1}\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right) M_{2}\left(\left(b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right) \cdots M_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)\binom{\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)}{\operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{k+1}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)} \\
= & \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} M_{1}\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right) M_{2}\left(\left(b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right) \cdots M_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)\binom{1}{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

A simple calculation yields that $\operatorname{det} M_{k}(t) \equiv 0$ for $t \in \mathbb{R}, k \geq 1$. Thus the function matrix $M_{k}(t)$ can be expressed as

$$
M_{k}(t)=\alpha(t)^{T} \beta_{k}(t)
$$

where

$$
\alpha(t)=(\cos \pi t,-\sin \pi t)
$$

and

$$
\beta_{k}(t)=\left(\frac{1}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1} \cos (4 j+1) \pi t,-\frac{1}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1} \sin (4 j+1) \pi t\right)
$$

On the other hand, one can check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{k}(t) \alpha\left(b_{k+1}^{-1} t\right)^{T} & =\frac{1}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1}(\cos (4 j+1) \pi t \cos b_{k+1}^{-1} \pi t+\sin (4 j+1) \pi t \sin b_{k+1}^{-1} \pi t) \\
& =\frac{1}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1} \cos \left(4 j+1-b_{k+1}^{-1}\right) \pi t \\
& :=f_{k}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(1-f_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)\right) & =\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1} \sin ^{2} \frac{\left(4 j+1-b_{k+1}^{-1}\right)\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t}{2} \\
& \leq \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1}\left(\frac{\left(4 j+1-b_{k+1}^{-1}\right)\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t}{2}\right)^{2} \\
& \leq \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{p_{k}} \sum_{j=0}^{p_{k}-1}\left(2 p_{k}\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)^{2} \\
& \leq \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} 2^{3-2 k} t^{2}<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

the infinite product $\prod_{k=1}^{\infty} f_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)$ converges uniformly on each compact subset of $\mathbb{R}$.

From the above discussion, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\begin{array}{c}
\operatorname{Re} \widehat{\mu}_{1}(t) \\
\operatorname{Im} \widehat{\mu}_{1}(t)
\end{array}\right) \\
= & \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} M_{1}\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right) M_{2}\left(\left(b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right) \cdots M_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)\binom{1}{0} \\
= & \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \alpha\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right)^{T} \beta_{1}\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right) \alpha\left(\left(b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)^{T} \beta_{2}\left(\left(b_{2} b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right) \cdots \alpha\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)^{T} \beta_{k}\left(\left(b_{k} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)\binom{1}{0} \\

= & \alpha\left(b_{1}^{-1} t\right)^{T} \prod_{n=1}^{\infty} f_{n}\left(\left(b_{n} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\widehat{\mu}(t)=\widehat{\mu}_{1}(t)=e^{-b_{1}^{-1} \pi t i} \prod_{n=1}^{\infty} f_{n}\left(\left(b_{n} \cdots b_{1}\right)^{-1} t\right)$ as desired.

$$

Let $p_{i, j}:=\left|m_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j}{c}+t\right)\right|^{2}$ and $x_{i, j}:=\sum_{\tilde{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{i, j}}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j}{c}+\tilde{\lambda}+t\right)\right|^{2}$, we have $\sum_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1} \sum_{j=0}^{\gamma_{1}-1} p_{i, j} x_{i, j}=1$. For any $i \in\left\{0,1, \ldots, q_{1}-1\right\}$, let $L_{i}=\left\{i+q_{1} j: 0 \leq j \leq \gamma_{1}-1\right\}$, then $\left(c, \mathcal{D}_{1}, L_{i}\right)$ is Hadamard triple, that is,

$$
\sum_{j=0}^{\gamma_{1}-1} p_{i, j}=\sum_{j=0}^{\gamma_{1}-1}\left|m_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j}{c}+t\right)\right|^{2}=1
$$

Since $\left\{j_{i}: 0 \leq i \leq q_{1}-1\right\} \subset\left\{0,1, \ldots, \gamma_{1}-1\right\}, \Gamma$ is a bi-zero set of $\omega_{>1}$, then

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1} \max \left\{x_{i, 0}, x_{i, 1}, \ldots, x_{i, \gamma_{1}-1}\right\} \leq 1
$$

By Lemma 2.13, we have

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1} \sum_{\tilde{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{i, j}}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j}{c}+\tilde{\lambda}+t\right)\right|^{2}=1
$$

for all $j \in\left\{0,1, \ldots, \gamma_{1}-1\right\}$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\tilde{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{i, 0}}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}\left(\frac{i}{c}+\tilde{\lambda}+t\right)\right|^{2} \\
= & \sum_{\tilde{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{i, 1}}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1}}{c}+\tilde{\lambda}+t\right)\right|^{2} \\
\vdots & \\
= & \sum_{\tilde{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{i, \gamma_{1}-1}}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1}\left(\gamma_{1}-1\right)}{c}+\tilde{\lambda}+t\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $i \in\left\{0,1, \ldots, q_{1}-1\right\}$. Hence

$$
Q_{\Gamma, \omega_{>1}}(t)=\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma}\left|\widehat{\omega}_{>1}(t+\gamma)\right|^{2}=1
$$

for $t \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \mathbb{Q}$. By the continuity of $Q_{\Gamma, \omega_{>1}}$, we have $Q_{\Gamma, \omega_{>1}}(t) \equiv 1$ for $t \in \mathbb{R}$. Theorem 2.1 implies that $\omega_{>1}$ is a spectral measure with the spectrum $\Gamma$.

Remark 5.2. From the proof of Lemma 5.1, it is easy to see that $\omega_{>k}$ is a spectral measure for all $k \geq 1$ provided that $\nu$ is a spectral measure. Furthermore, if $\Gamma_{k}$ containing 0 is a spectrum of $\omega_{>k}$, then for any $\left\{j_{i}: 0 \leq i \leq q_{k}-1\right\} \subset\left\{0,1, \ldots, \gamma_{k}-\right.$ $1\}$, the set

$$
\Gamma_{k+1}=\bigcup_{i=0}^{q_{k}-1}\left(\frac{i+q_{k} j_{i}}{c}+\Lambda_{i+q_{k} j_{i}}\right)
$$

is a spectrum of $\omega_{>k+1}$ if $\Gamma_{k+1} \neq \emptyset$, where $c=q_{k} \gamma_{k}$ and $\Lambda_{i+q_{k} j_{i}}=\mathbb{Z} \cap\left(\frac{\Gamma_{k}}{d_{k}}-\frac{i+q_{k} j_{i}}{c}\right)$.
Proposition 5.3. Let $\nu$ be defined by (5.1) is a spectral measure with bounded $\left\{t_{k}\right\}$ and $\left\{\gamma_{k}\right\}$, then
(i) If $\gamma_{i} \nmid t_{i+1}$ for some $i$, then $\gamma_{i+1} \mid l_{i+1}$.
(ii) If $\gamma_{i} \nmid t_{i+1}, \operatorname{gcd}\left(l_{i+1}, t_{i+1}\right)=1$, and $d_{i+2}=l_{i+2}$ is an integer satisfying $t_{i+1} \mid l_{i+2}$ for some $i$, then $t_{i+1} \gamma_{i+2} \mid l_{i+2}$.

Proof. By Remark 5.2, we only need to prove the case that $i=1$. Let $\Lambda$ be a spectrum of $\nu$ with $0 \in \Lambda$, then Lemma 5.1 shows that

$$
\Gamma=\bigcup_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}+\Lambda_{i+q_{1} j_{i}}\right)=\bigcup_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1}\left(\frac{i}{c}+\frac{j_{i}}{\gamma_{1}}+\Lambda_{i, j_{i}}\right)
$$

is a spectrum of $\omega_{>1}$ if $\Gamma \neq \emptyset$.
(i) If $\gamma_{1} \nmid t_{2}$. We set $j_{0}=0$, and for $i \neq 0$ we set $j_{i}=0$ if $\frac{t_{2}}{\gamma_{2}} \not \equiv t_{2} \frac{i}{c}(\bmod 1)$, $j_{i}=1$ if $\frac{t_{1}}{\gamma_{2}} \equiv t_{2} \frac{i}{c}(\bmod 1)$. Then $\gamma_{1} \nmid t_{2}$ implies that $\frac{t_{2}}{\gamma_{2}} \not \equiv t_{2} \frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}(\bmod 1)$ for $i \neq 0$.

Using (5.3) for $\omega_{>1}$, the spectrum $\Gamma$ has the following multi-stage decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Gamma & =\bigcup_{i=0}^{q_{1}-1}\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}+\Lambda_{i, j_{i}}\right) \\
& =d_{2} \bigcup_{i^{\prime}=0}^{q_{2}-1} \bigcup_{j^{\prime}=0}^{\gamma_{2}-1}\left(\frac{i^{\prime}+q_{2} j^{\prime}}{c}+\Gamma_{i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Gamma_{i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}}=\mathbb{Z} \cap\left(\frac{\Gamma}{d_{2}}-\frac{i^{\prime}+q_{2} j^{\prime}}{c}\right)$. Since $0 \in \Gamma_{0,0} \neq \emptyset$, by (5.4), we have $\Gamma_{0, j^{\prime}} \neq \emptyset$ for all $0 \leq j^{\prime} \leq \gamma_{2}-1$. Choose an integer $z_{0}^{\prime} \in \Gamma_{0,1}$, then there exists $\left(i, j_{i}\right) \in$ $\left\{0,1, \ldots, q_{1}-1\right\} \times\left\{0,1, \ldots, \gamma_{1}-1\right\}$ and an integer $z_{0} \in \Lambda_{i, j_{i}}$ such that

$$
\frac{l_{2}}{t_{2}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma_{2}}+z_{0}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}+z_{0}
$$

This yields that $i=j_{i}=0$ since $\frac{l_{2}}{\gamma_{2}} \not \equiv t_{2} \frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}(\bmod 1)$ for any $1 \leq i \leq q_{1}-1$. Hence $\frac{l_{2}}{\gamma_{2}}+l_{2} z_{0}^{\prime}=t_{2} z_{0}$, showing that $\gamma_{2} \mid l_{2}$.
(ii) If $\gamma_{1} \nmid t_{2}, \operatorname{gcd}\left(l_{2}, t_{2}\right)=1$, and $d_{3}=l_{3}$ is an integer satisfying $t_{2} \mid l_{3}$, We set $j_{0}=0$, and for $i \neq 0$ we set $j_{i}=0$ if $\frac{t_{2} i}{c} \notin \mathbb{Z}, j_{i}=1$ if $\frac{t_{2} i}{c} \in \mathbb{Z}$. Hence $0 \in \Lambda_{0,0} \subset \Gamma$, $\Gamma$ is a spectrum of $\omega_{>1}$. Since $\gamma_{1} \nmid t_{2}$, one can check that

$$
\left(\frac{i+q_{1} j_{i}}{c}\right) t_{2}=\frac{t_{2} i}{c}+\frac{t_{2}}{\gamma_{1}} j_{i} \notin \mathbb{Z}
$$

for any $i \neq 0$. By using (5.5) and the fact that $\Lambda_{i, j_{i}}, \Gamma_{i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}} \subset \mathbb{Z}$ for any $i, i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}$, we have $l_{2} \Gamma_{0,0} \subset t_{2} \Lambda_{0,0}$. It follows from $\operatorname{gcd}\left(l_{2}, t_{2}\right)=1$ that $\Gamma_{0,0} \subset t_{2} \mathbb{Z}$.

For any $0 \leq \iota \leq q_{2}-1$, choose $0 \leq \tau_{\iota} \leq \gamma_{2}-1$ and let

$$
\Lambda^{*}=\bigcup_{\iota=0}^{q_{2}-1}\left(\frac{\iota+q_{2} \tau_{\iota}}{c}+\Gamma_{\iota, \tau_{\iota}}\right)
$$

where $\tau_{\iota}=0$ for $\iota=0$. Then $\Lambda^{*}$ is a spectrum of the measure $\omega_{>2}$ by Remark 5.2.
Using multi-stage decomposition again, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Lambda^{*} & =\bigcup_{\iota=0}^{q_{2}-1}\left(\frac{\iota+q_{2} \tau_{\iota}}{c}+\Gamma_{\iota, \tau_{\iota}}\right) \\
& =d_{3} \bigcup_{s=0}^{q_{3}-1} \bigcup_{t=0}^{\gamma_{3}-1}\left(\frac{s+q_{3} t}{c}+\Lambda_{s, t}^{*}\right) \\
& =l_{3} \bigcup_{s=0}^{q_{3}-1} \bigcup_{t=0}^{\gamma_{3}-1}\left(\frac{s}{c}+\frac{t}{\gamma_{3}}+\Lambda_{s, t}^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Lambda_{s, t}^{*}=\mathbb{Z} \cap\left(\frac{\Lambda^{*}}{d_{3}}-\frac{s+q_{3} t}{c}\right)$. That $d_{3}=l_{3}$ implies that $t_{3}=1$ and $\gamma_{2} \nmid t_{3}$, hence $\gamma_{3} \mid l_{3}$ by (i), it follows that

$$
l_{3}\left(\frac{t}{\gamma_{3}}+\Lambda_{0, t}^{*}\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}
$$

for any $0 \leq t \leq \gamma_{3}-1$. It can be seen that

$$
l_{3}\left(\frac{t}{\gamma_{3}}+\Lambda_{0, t}^{*}\right) \subset \Gamma_{0,0} \subset t_{2} \mathbb{Z}
$$

Since $t_{2} \mid l_{3}$, let $l_{3}=l_{3}^{\prime} t_{2}$, then $l_{3}^{\prime}\left(\frac{t}{\gamma_{3}}+\Lambda_{0, t}^{*}\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}$ for any $0 \leq t \leq \gamma_{3}-1$. Consequently, we have $\gamma_{3} \mid l_{3}^{\prime}$ and $t_{2} \gamma_{3} \mid l_{3}$, completing the proof.

Proposition 5.4. Suppose that $2 \mid p_{k}$ for all $k \geq 1$. If $\nu$ in (4.4) is a spectral measure, then $2 \mid b_{k+1}$ for all $k \geq 1$.

Proof. Since $2 \mid p_{k}, k \geq 1$, we get

$$
D_{p_{k}}=D_{2} \oplus D_{\frac{p_{k}}{2}}
$$

The measure $\nu$ can be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu= & \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} D_{2}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} D_{\frac{p_{1}}{2}}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1}\left(p_{1}-\frac{1+k_{1}^{-1}}{2}\right) D_{2}} * \cdots * \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k}\right)^{-1} D_{2}} * \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k}\right)^{-1} D_{\frac{p_{k}}{2}}} * \\
& \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k}\right)^{-1}\left(p_{k}-\frac{1+k_{k+1}^{-1}}{2}\right) D_{2}} * \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k} b_{k+1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}} * \delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{k} b_{k+1}\right)^{-1} D_{\frac{p_{k+1}}{2}}} * \cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

If $2 \mid b_{k+1}$ does not hold for all $k \geq 1$, that is, there exists $n \geq 1$ such that $b_{n+1} \in 2 \mathbb{Z}+1$. Then we have

$$
\mathcal{Z}\left(\widehat{\delta}_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{n+1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}}\right)=\frac{b_{1} \cdots b_{n+1}}{2}(2 \mathbb{Z}+1) \subset \frac{b_{1} \cdots b_{n}}{2}(2 \mathbb{Z}+1)=\mathcal{Z}\left(\widehat{\delta}_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{n}\right)^{-1} D_{2}}\right)
$$

Writing $\nu=\delta_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{n+1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}} * \nu^{\prime}$. Since $\mathcal{Z}\left(\widehat{\delta}_{\left(b_{1} \cdots b_{n+1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}}\right) \subset \mathcal{Z}(\widehat{\nu^{\prime}})$, if $\Lambda$ is a spectrum of $\nu$, then $\Lambda$ is a bi-zero set of $\nu^{\prime}$. But $\Lambda$ can not be a spectrum of $\nu$ by Lemma 2.2. That is a contradiction.

For the measure $\nu$ as in (4.6), we may change the digit sets in each level into the consecutive digit sets by adjusting the contraction ratios as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu= & \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} D_{p_{1}}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1} D_{p_{2}}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1} 2^{-1}\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right) D_{2}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1} 2^{-1}\left(\frac{b_{2}}{2}\right)^{-1} D_{p_{3}}} * \\
& \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} \cdot b_{2}^{-1} 2^{-1} \cdot\left(\frac{b_{2}}{2}\right)^{-1} 2^{-1}\left(b_{3}\left(2 p_{2}-1\right)-1\right) D_{2}} * \cdots \\
= & \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} D_{p_{1}}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1} D_{p_{2}}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1}\left(\frac{b_{3}\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)}{2}\right)^{-1} D_{p_{3}}} * \\
& \delta_{b_{1}^{-1} b_{2}^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1}\left(\frac{b_{3}\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)}{2}\right)^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{2}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1} D_{2}} * \cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

Let

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
b_{1}^{\prime \prime}=b_{1}, & b_{2 k+1}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{2}{b_{k+1}\left(2 p_{k}-1\right)-1} \\
b_{2}^{\prime \prime}=b_{2}, & b_{2 k+2}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{b_{k+2}\left(b_{k+1}\left(2 p_{k}-1\right)-1\right)}{2}
\end{array}
$$

and

$$
p_{1}^{\prime \prime}=p_{1}, \quad p_{2}^{\prime \prime}=p_{2}, \quad p_{2 k+1}^{\prime \prime}=2, \quad p_{2 k+2}^{\prime \prime}=p_{k+2}
$$

Then $\nu$ can be rewritten as

$$
\nu=\delta_{b_{1}^{\prime \prime}-1} D_{p_{1}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{2}^{\prime \prime}-1 D_{p_{2}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{1}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{2}^{\prime \prime-1} b_{3}^{\prime \prime-1} D_{p_{3}^{\prime \prime}} * \cdots
$$

Accordingly, let

$$
\omega_{>k}=\delta_{b_{k+1}^{\prime \prime}-1} D_{p_{k+1}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{k+1}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{k+2}^{\prime \prime}-1} D_{p_{k+2}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{k+1}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{k+2}^{\prime \prime}-1 b_{k+3}^{\prime \prime}-1} D_{p_{k+3}^{\prime \prime}} * \cdots
$$

Theorem 5.5. Let $2 \mid p_{k}$ for all $k \geq 1$ and $\left\{b_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty}$ be bounded. If $\nu$ in (5.8) is a spectral measure, then $p_{2} \mid b_{2}$ and $2 p_{k} \mid b_{k}$ for $k \geq 3$.

Proof. Proposition 5.4 implies that $2 \mid b_{k}$ for all $k \geq 2$. By (5.6), (5.7) and Proposition 5.3(i), we have $p_{2} \mid b_{2}$.

From Lemma 5.1, it follows that $\omega_{>1}$ as in (5.9) is a spectral measure where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{>1} & =\delta_{b_{2}^{\prime \prime}-1} D_{p_{2}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{2}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{3}^{\prime \prime-1} D_{p_{3}^{\prime \prime}} * \delta_{b_{2}^{\prime \prime}-1} b_{3}^{\prime \prime-1} b_{4}^{\prime \prime-1} D_{p_{4}^{\prime \prime}} * \cdots \\
& =\delta_{b_{2}^{-1}} D_{p_{2}} * \delta_{b_{2}^{-1}}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1} D_{2} * \delta_{b_{2}^{-1}}\left(\frac{2}{b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1}\right)^{-1}\left(\frac{b_{3}\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)}{2}\right)^{-1} D_{p_{3}} * \cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $p_{2}$ is even and $\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)$ is odd, we get $p_{2} \nmid\left(b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)$ and $\operatorname{gcd}\left(2, b_{2}\left(2 p_{1}-1\right)-1\right)=1$. Repeating the above argument, we conclude that $p_{k} \mid \frac{b_{k}}{2}$ for all $k \geq 3$, completing the proof.

abstract:
Consider a Moran-type iterated function system (IFS) \( \{\phi_{k,d}\}_{d\in
D_{2p_k}, k\geq 1} \), where each contraction map is defined as \[
\phi_{k,d}(x) = (-1)^d b_k^{-1}(x + d), \] with integer sequences \(
\{b_k\}_{k=1}^\infty \) and \( \{p_k\}_{k=1}^\infty \) satisfying \( b_k \geq
2p_k \geq 2 \), and digit sets \( D_{2p_k} = \{0, 1, \ldots, 2p_k - 1\} \) for
all \( k \geq 1 \). We first prove that this IFS uniquely generates a Borel
probability measure \( \mu \). Furthermore, under the divisibility constraints
\[ p_2 \mid b_2, \quad 2 \mid b_2, \quad \text{and} \quad 2p_k \mid b_k \
\text{for} \ k \geq 3, \] with \(\{b_k\}_{k=1}^\infty\) bounded, we prove that
\( \mu \) is a spectral measure, that is, $ L^2(\mu) $ admits an orthogonal
basis of exponentials. To fully characterize the spectral properties, we
introduce a multi-stage decomposition strategy for spectrums. By imposing the
additional hypothesis that all parameters \( p_k \) are even, we establish a
complete characterization of \( \mu \)'s spectrality. This result unifies and
extends the frameworks proposed in \cite{An-He2014, Deng2022, Wu2024},
providing a generalized criterion for such measures.
